results.title: Problem of conservation: Our natural resources
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Provides a broad overview of developing crises in world natural resources. Establishes man’s reliance upon and misuse of such resources and describes current conservation efforts. Produced in collaboration with Allan A. Sollers, author of “Ours is our Earth.”

results.title: Problems of conservation
results.brief_description: Highlights problems in the United States associated with the depletion of non-renewable natural resources; forest, mineral, wildlife and the associated problem of increasing air pollution. Discusses intervention strategies.

results.title: Solar water heating
results.creator_credit: Roger Morse, Ted Davey, S.T. Evans and CSIRO
results.brief_description: Collecting solar energy for use in water heaters. A CSIRO scientist explains how the absorbers work and, with the aid of diagrams, how they operate on the principle of thermo-cyclic-flow. Their installation and economy are also demonstrated.

results.title: Soil
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Shows what soil is and how it is formed - then illustrates the damaging effects of water and wind erosion. Another damaging depletion is the loss of nutrients in the soil. Illustrates with on the spot examples of how the U.S. conservation service in 1969 combated these projects that range from contour ploughing to land use planning.

results.title: Orbost v Orbost
results.creator_credit: David Wood, John Sparkes and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Orbost in Victoria is a fairly normal country town, but it has one outstanding feature - two football clubs. Every winter, football becomes the focal point in the lives of most of the local people, and it provides a good deal of their social life. In this film the two local teams compete in the district final, and football fever reaches its highest pitch.

results.title: Wildlife
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Explains the need for conservation of wildlife in order to preserve the ecological balance of nature. Describes the endangered status of many species today, what has been done to control impending extinction in the past, and what can be done in the future through refuges. In collaboration with Allan A. Sollers, author of “Ours is the Earth”.

results.title: Be it ever so humble
results.creator_credit: Ron Iddon, John Sparkes and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Shot in Queensland, this film examines the development in styles of houses in Australia, from the slab hut to the contemporary brick house. Suitable for Upper Secondary-Tertiary level students.

results.title: A Land fit for heroes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Examines the harsh reality that lay behind the concept of parcelling out plots of land for soldiers returning from both the first and second world wars. Uses archival footage, interviews and old radio broadcasts. Reporter - Ron Iddon. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Snatch [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Guy Ritchie, Matthew Vaughn and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Guy Ritchie’s second feature follows on seamlessly from his first: the music video/caper movie, “Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels”. It’s cast - peppered with Hollywood stars Benicio Del Toro, Dennis Farina and Brad Pitt - portray a crowd of London small-timers torturing, mutilating and wise-cracking their way across Ritchie’s home territory: ludicrous plots, racial stereotypes and groovy pop music, all in the name of derisively good fun. If “Lock, Stock” was an escapade into guilt-free sick violence, then “Snatch” is exactly the same.

results.title: Right Through the Shearing Time
results.creator_credit: John Maybe, Trevor Stockley and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
This film features sheep shearing at Moree and Yass, in New South Wales, and provides extensive information about this distinctive Australian industry. It also shows the life of the seasonal workers who are employed in this rural activity.
